properties.title: Agi's Counter
properties.description: A is for Agiâ€™s Counter: a recent addition to Crown Heights, my neighborhood! Agiâ€™s is a modern Jewish/Hungarian take on the traditional lunch counter, serving up delicious staples full of flavor. The motif in this illustration is a traditional folk tulip, the national flower of Hungary, as their wine list is 100% Hungarian.

properties.title: Bunny
properties.description: B is for Bunny, a wonderful little gem in Bed-Stuy. Bunny serves modern Turkish fare with an ever-changing daily menu, so you know youâ€™re getting the freshest and the best. I was inspired by traditional Iznik handpainted tile for this one.

properties.title: Bar Camillo
properties.description: C is for Bar Camillo. Where do I even begin with this restaurant, one of my absolute favorites? Theyâ€™re a sister restaurant of the esteemed Locanda in Clinton Hill, but their menu is focused on Roman pinsa and a long list of Negroni specialities. You absolutely must order the insalata di cicoria, itâ€™s the most simple and heavenly salad that I could never go without. The anchovies are pretty spectacular, too.

properties.title: Do or Dive
properties.description: D for Do or Dive, one of my Bed-Stuy staples. Cheap drinks, good vibes, dogs allowed. Order the Coffee Thing in the summer and hang out in the backyard. This place really knows how to hit the spot ğŸ’¯

properties.title: Elsa
properties.description: E for Elsa, one of my favorite cocktail bars. When I used to work nearby, this was my staple for happy hour â€” I love their generous and luxe cheese boards and sazeracs on the cheap. Their interior design is KILLER, even the bathrooms feel like an experience.

properties.title: Fiaschetteria 'Pistoia'
properties.description: One of my favorite things about living in New York is you can wander down any given street and find some of the best food you never knew was there. Fisachetteria Pistoia became a go-to whenever I have a hankering for pasta after happening upon it in the West Village, because their cacio e pepe with handrolled pici is to die for, and their house wine carafe served with tiny duralex glasses transports me immediately to Italy.

properties.title: Golda
properties.description: I love a cafe / restaurant combo and this is one of the best, melding mouthwatering mediterranean flavors into breakfast pastries, lunch sandwiches, and dinner plates ã€°ï¸ their breakfast sandwich with harissa jam is not to be missed, & Iâ€™m only a little obsessed with their branding & interior design.

properties.title: Hart's
properties.description: Hartâ€™s is well known for good reason. They turned into a market during the pandemic selling their house made specialties, and honestly I was a little sad when they went back to service because I canâ€™t buy their tahini spread & wholesale wine on the regular anymore :(  It can be hard to get a reservation for their tiny dining space, but I always have luck walking in for a waitlist table and grabbing a cocktail at Glorietta Baldy next door while I wait (almost made my G for them!) - makes for a great night out.

properties.title: I Sodi
properties.description: ah, the elusive white whale of my NYC Italian dining adventure. I almost ate here once, but a couple ran, literally RAN, to beat my boyfriend and I to the door as we walked up and they got the last open table. Someday Iâ€™ll check this one off my list, or maybe Iâ€™ll just go back to Italy Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

properties.title: Jack's Wife Freda
properties.description: A stand-by staple for all occasions. This has been a go-to since one of my first trips to New York before I moved here; I sat alone in a corner table and had green shakshuka and a cocktail while I read a book â€¦ I felt SO incredibly ~new yorker~  There are multiple locations and you canâ€™t go wrong with any of them, unless youâ€™re looking for a big table for brunch because youâ€™ll be waiting for hours. But itâ€™s probably worth the wait.

properties.title: Kubeh
properties.description: Mediterranean & Middle Eastern cuisines are one of my all-time favorite. Kubeh has a fantastic selection of mezes and yummy things, and they have arak service with multiple options which is just truly *chefs kiss*

properties.title: Lupa
properties.description: A friend of mine used to work at this cozy Roman restaurant, and it was such a fun place to visit and sit at the bar during her shift. This is where my love for amaro began ğŸ–¤

properties.title: Miss Ada
properties.description: A canâ€™t-miss Mediterranean masterpiece. I have dreams about the whipped ricotta and sweet potato hummus. Their name is a play on the Hebrew word for restaurant, â€˜misadaâ€™. This design is inspired by traditional Israeli paper cutting, which is a gorgeous thing to google.

properties.title: Neptune Diner
properties.description: Thereâ€™s a special place in my heart for classic diners. I always find one when Iâ€™m on a trip, but have a lot left in New York to try. Neptune Diner is in my neighborhood on the border of Crown Heights & Prospect Heights, and next time Iâ€™m craving a tuna melt, Iâ€™m headed this way.

properties.title: Oxomoco
properties.description: A Michelin-starred Mexican restaurant in Greenpoint. Their menu is entirely small sharing plates which is one of my favorite ways to eat â€” a little bite of everything, please!

properties.title: Pietro Nolita
properties.description: Pietro Nolita - the most pink restaurant youâ€™ll ever find yourself in, in a cozy half basement in Nolita. their specialties are Italian classics, and Iâ€™ve never been so pleased with a plate of spaghetti pomodoro ğŸ

properties.title: Quan Sushi

properties.title: Rialto Grande
properties.description: My favorite local bar in Crown Heights ğŸ–¤ They have amazing cocktails, great bartenders, plenty of gold tinsel, and the whole place just feels like being cozy inside a mid century credenza. Highly recommend ğŸ’¯

properties.title: SmÃ¸r

I found SmÃ¸r when I had a hankering for a cardamom bun and it became an instant favorite ğŸ’• they have more than pastries, too, with (very good) Nordic-inspired lunch and dinner.

properties.title: Taiyaki
properties.description: Taiyaki is a baked fish-shaped cone stuffed with bean curd or custard, and filled with soft serve ğŸ¦ I die. You can get any combo of toppings, I highly recommend the stick of mochi. Matcha is my favorite soft-serve flavor so hereâ€™s a green scaly T ğŸ’š

properties.title: Ume

properties.title: Vanessa's Dumpling House
properties.description: Iâ€™m always down for dumplings, and this classic hits the spot every time ğŸ¥Ÿ Itâ€™ll always feel extra special to me as it played a big part in my boyfriendâ€™s and my early dating <3  all I can say is, order everything you can and you wonâ€™t be disappointed.

properties.title: Wildair
properties.description: W for Wildair, one of the first places I had truly good scallops (!) and their natural wine list is no joke. a truly great spot for some small plates in the lower east side ğŸ«¶

properties.title: Bar Tulix
properties.description: X for Bar Tulix - I was so sad when Xilonen closed, a vegan Mexican spot in Greenpoint by the same crew as Oxomoco (see my â€˜Oâ€™ matchbox!). properties.title: Amor Y Amargo
properties.description: A cocktail bar specializing solely in bitters, I have had some truly creative and delicious drinks here. The way they recreate classics & come up with entirely new flavors using only amari is incredible!

properties.title: Zucker's Bagels & Smoked Fish
properties.description: It wouldnâ€™t be a New York restaurant series without a bagel shop, and Zuckerâ€™s has never let me down. Whatâ€™s your go-to bagel spot?? ğŸ‘€ğŸ¥¯

properties.title: Zero Otto Nove
properties.description: Zero for Zero Otto Nove - Iâ€™m a little shocked Iâ€™ve made it through 27 restaurants in NYC and this is only the second pizza spot. This is a Neapolitan pizzeria in the Bronx that has been on my list for a long time - conventiently for me, they also have a location in lower Manhattan

properties.title: 1 If By Land, 2 If By Sea

It references Revereâ€™s secret signal to inform the route the British were taking at the outset of the Revolutionary War ğŸ•¯ï¸ğŸğŸ›¶

properties.title: Rule of Thirds
properties.description: Rule of Thirds in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is a phenomenal Japanese restaurant. Have had very fun times with friends here, the menu is perfect for sharing lots of things. Their hamachi collar is incredible - this was the first place I had a fish collar and was a little confused at first how to eat it, but very quickly forgot my manners and just tore in because it was so delicious ğŸ˜‹

properties.title: The Four Horsemen
properties.description: 4 is for The Four Horsemen - this natural wine bar has been on my list for a long time but I havenâ€™t made it yet! Fun fact, it was opened by the lead singer of LCD Soundsystem ğŸª©

properties.title: Five Leaves
properties.description: Five Leaves in Greenpoint - this tiny corner spot is great not only for the food but also for the location! one of my favorite corners on a nice day â˜€ï¸ itâ€™s right next to McCarren Park and thereâ€™s a Saturday vintage pop-up on the sidewalk ğŸ’¯

properties.title: Bar 6
properties.description: A French Moroccan bistro in Greenwich Village. Sixth Ave is kind of a weird amalgamation of different businesses and busy traffic, but Bar Six is a friendly little hideaway from the chaos ğŸ’« I really enjoyed drawing the tile pattern for this one ğŸ™‚

properties.title: No. 7 Restaurant
properties.description: This spot is along Prospect Heightsâ€™ â€œrestaurant rowâ€ on Vanderbilt, where there are honestly just too many good places to choose from. properties.title: 1OR8
properties.description: A Japanese restaurant in Fort Greene. They have regular seating with a full menu, or a sushi counter for omakase â€” get you a spot that can do both.

properties.title: The Nines
properties.description: A classic supper club with pianos and caviar, I cannot wait to dine here someday.
